title: RS22154
content: The Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, initiated in 1986 under GATT, concluded in 1994 with the signing of the WTO Agreement. This agreement requires countries to accept all negotiated trade agreements. It includes long-standing GATT obligations and new agreements, as well as the Dispute Settlement Understanding for resolving disputes between WTO Members. The Dispute Settlement Understanding (DSU) governs disputes between WTO Members under various agreements. The process involves consultations, panels, appeals, and adoption of reports by the Dispute Settlement Body (DSB). Non-compliance may lead to compensation or retaliatory measures. The Uruguay Round Agreement Act (URAA) implemented WTO decisions in the United States. The URAA implemented the WTO Agreement and other Uruguay Round agreements in the United States, addressing legal effects, prohibiting private remedies for alleged violations, and requiring the USTR to inform Congress of disputes. It also imposes requirements on agencies for implementing WTO decisions and considers the Uruguay Round agreements non-self-executing like previous trade agreements. The URAA implements WTO agreements in the US, setting out new authorities and repeals. It also mandates a 60-day consultation period with Congress and allows for committees to vote on proposed actions. Section 129 of the URAA details the procedures for implementing adverse WTO panel and Appellate Body reports in U.S. safeguards, antidumping, and countervailing duty proceedings conducted by the USITC, USTR, and Commerce Department. Safeguards proceedings involve investigating whether increased imports cause serious injury to domestic industries, with initiation possible through industry petitions, government requests, or self-motivation. The President may restrict imports if serious injury is found to a domestic industry by imported goods. Antidumping and countervailing duty investigations can be initiated by petition or Department of Commerce motion to determine if products are sold below fair value or subsidized. USITC determines if imports cause material injury to domestic industry, imposing duties accordingly. If dumping or subsidization and injury are found, antidumping or countervailing duties will be imposed on imports. The Commerce Department's use of "zeroing" in calculating margins has been challenged in WTO disputes, with U.S. courts allowing the practice but facing criticism. In response, the Commerce Department has abandoned zeroing in original investigations and proposed modifications for future antidumping proceedings. Additionally, the Department has issued new antidumping determinations in cases where specific orders have been challenged in WTO proceedings.
